prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. How many of the 200 smallest positive integers are congruent to 1 (mod 9)?
solution: An integer congruent to 1 (mod 9) can be written in the form $9n + 1$ for some integer $n$.  We want to count the number of integers $n$ such that $$ 1 \le 9n + 1 \le 200. $$Subtracting 1 from all parts of the inequality, we get $0 \le 9n \le 199$.  Dividing by 9 we get $0 \le n \le 22\, \frac{1}{9}$.  There are $22 - 0 + 1 = \boxed{23}$ values of $n$ corresponding to positive integers from 1 to 200 inclusive that are congruent to 1 (mod 9).
gpt_response:
To find out how many numbers are congruent to 1 (mod 9) out of the 200 smallest positive integers, we can start by counting by 9s. That means we start with 1, then add 9 to get 10, add 9 again to get 19, and so on.

We can see that every 9 numbers will be congruent to 1 (mod 9) because when we divide them by 9, there will always be a remainder of 1.

So out of the 200 smallest positive integers, we can count how many groups of 9 there are. Since 200 divided by 9 is around 22 with a remainder of 2, that means there are 22 groups of 9 and 2 more numbers left over.

Therefore, there are 22 groups of numbers congruent to 1 (mod 9), which is 22 x 9 = 198 numbers. So out of the 200 smallest positive integers, 198 of them are congruent to 1 (mod 9).
solution_prompt:

So out of the 200 smallest positive integers, we can count how many groups of 9 there are. Since 200 divided by 9 is around 22 with a remainder of 2, that means there are 22 groups of 9 and 2 more numbers left over.

Therefore, there are 22 groups of numbers congruent to 1 (mod 9), which is 22 x 9 = 198 numbers. So out of the 200 smallest positive integers, 198 of them are congruent to 1 (mod 9).
